questions.text: A 25-year-old student goes for a Dubai Dune Safari. The environmental temperature is 41 degrees Celsius and the relative humidity is 20%. Which option best describes the mechanism of heat loss in this individual?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Evaporation 
When the environmental temperature is more than the body temperature, there is a tendency to gain heat, mainly by radiation. Heat gain causes the core body temperature to rise. The anterior hypothalamus, which is the heat loss centre, causes vasodilation and sweating. Evaporation of the sweat causes a fall in the core body temperature to set point of 37 degrees Celsius.

questions.text: A patient has a GFR of 100mL/min, urine flow rate of 2mL/min and a plasma glucose concentration of 200mg/dL. If the TmG (transport maxima for Glucose) is 250mg/min, what would be this patient’s rate of glucose excretion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

0mg/min
Filtered rate of glucose (mg/min) = GFR (mL/min) X plasma glucose (mg/mL)
                  = 100 X 2
                  = 200mg/min
The TmG is 250mg/min. Since the filtered rate of glucose is less than the TmG, all of the filtered glucose will be reabsorbed and there is no glucose in urine.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient is brought to the Emergency after a road traffic accident causing a traumatic head injury. Within hours he begins eating objects such as paper, is unable to maintain attention, and displays increased sexual activity. He is diagnosed with Kluver- Bucy syndrome. A diagnostic MRI is ordered to confirm bilateral lesions of which of the following regions of the brain?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Temporal lobe 
Kluver-Bucy syndrome can be produced in experimental animals by removal of the amygdala from both temporal lobes. The syndrome is characterized by excessive sexual activity and a tendency to examine objects orally. Bilateral temporal lobe lesions produced by encephalitis or traumatic injury can produce at least some of these characteristics.

questions.text: The following graphs show the relationship between arterial pressure and blood flow. If the line in the center is normal, what does the one on the right indicate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The graph shows the relationship between pressure and flow. 
When the pressure in a small blood vessel is reduced, a point is reached at which no blood flows, even though the pressure is not zero. This is because the vessels are surrounded by tissues that exert a small but definite pressure on them, and when the intraluminal pressure falls below the tissue pressure, they collapse. The pressure at which flow ceases is called the critical closing pressure. 
The critical closing pressure may have different origins:-
•    Collateral inflow to the arteriolar meshwork
•    In certain situations, due to Rouleaux formation by red cells in the blood
•    External tissue pressure compressing the blood vessels
•    High vascular smooth muscle tone with closure of small arteries (as seen in terminal arterioles)
Increase in the sympathetic stimulation produces an increase in vasomotor tone and vasoconstriction and a shift of the curve to the right and a decreased slope. Critical closing pressure will occur at higher transmural pressures.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not useful for treating osteoporosis with hypercalcemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Abaloparatide
________________________________________
Explanation:
Zoledronate:
o    Zoledronate is a bisphosphonate that inhibits osteoclast activity, reducing bone resorption and calcium release into the bloodstream.
o    It is effective in managing osteoporosis and hypercalcemia of malignancy.
Denosumab:
o    Denosumab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits RANK-L, thereby reducing osteoclast activity and preventing bone resorption.
o    It is useful in treating osteoporosis and hypercalcemia associated with cancer.
Abaloparatide:
o    Abaloparatide is a synthetic analog of parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP).
o    It is an anabolic agent used to stimulate bone formation in osteoporosis. However, it increases calcium levels, making it unsuitable for osteoporosis with hypercalcemia.
Cinacalcet:
o    Cinacalcet is a calcimimetic agent that lowers serum calcium by enhancing the sensitivity of the calcium-sensing receptor in the parathyroid gland, reducing PTH secretion.
o    It is not a primary osteoporosis drug but is effective in treating hypercalcemia, especially in conditions like hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: A 35-year-old HIV-positive male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe flank pain radiating to the groin, accompanied by nausea. He has been on antiretroviral therapy for the past 8 months. A urinalysis reveals microscopic hematuria, and a non-contrast CT scan shows a radio-lucent stone in the left ureter.  Which of the following drug is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Indinavir
________________________________________
Explanation:
Indinavir  is a protease inhibitor (PI) used in antiretroviral therapy.
o    Indinavir is poorly soluble in urine, leading to the precipitation of the drug in the urinary tract.
o    This results in the formation of indinavir crystals or stones, which are radio-lucent on imaging.
o    Inadequate hydration increases the likelihood of indinavir crystallization and stone formation.

Tenofovir: Nucleotide reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI).
Tenofovir can cause renal tubular dysfunction or acute kidney injury, but it does not cause nephrolithiasis.
Dolutegravir:Integrase strand transfer inhibitor (INSTI).
Dolutegravir is primarily associated with weight gain and neuropsychiatric side effects (e.g., insomnia, dizziness).
Zidovudine: Nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI).
Zidovudine is associated with bone marrow suppression (anemia, neutropenia) and lactic acidosis, but it does not cause kidney stones or nephrolithiasis.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old male with a history of hypertension and diabetes presents with palpitations and shortness of breath. His ECG shown here. Blood pressure is stable, and there is no evidence of heart failure.
 
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial drug for rate control in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Verapamil
Explanation:
•    The patient has atrial fibrillation (AF) with a rapid ventricular response. The primary goal here is rate control.
•    Verapamil (or diltiazem), a calcium channel blocker, is effective for rate control in stable patients without heart failure.
•    Amiodarone is typically reserved for rhythm control or rate control in unstable patients or those with heart failure.
•    Digoxin is used for rate control in heart failure or in sedentary patients but is less effective for acute control in active patients.
•    Flecainide is a rhythm control agent and contraindicated without prior rate control in AF.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding antiplatelet drugs is true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Ticagrelor is a reversible P2Y12 receptor antagonist.

________________________________________
 Ticagrelor is a reversible P2Y12 receptor antagonist that inhibits platelet aggregation by blocking the P2Y12 ADP receptor.
Vorapaxar is an oral PAR-1 antagonist, not intravenous.
Ticagrelor has a faster onset of action than clopidogrel because it does not require hepatic activation.
Clopidogrel is a prodrug and requires metabolic activation by CYP enzymes, which delays its onset.
Omeprazole inhibits CYP2C19, an enzyme critical for clopidogrel activation.
Co-administration can reduce the antiplatelet efficacy of clopidogrel, increasing the risk of thrombotic events.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy with ADHD has been on stimulant medications but experiences severe insomnia and agitation. His physician decides to switch to a non-stimulant medication. Which alpha-2 agonist is most commonly used to treat ADHD in children?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Guanfacine

Explanation:

•    Guanfacine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist that modulates the prefrontal cortex by reducing sympathetic outflow, improving symptoms such as hyperactivity, impulsivity, and inattention in ADHD.
•    It is particularly effective for children with ADHD who cannot tolerate stimulant medications (e.g., methylphenidate) due to side effects like insomnia and agitation.
•    It has a calming effect and also helps with sleep regulation.
 
 atomoxetine is a non-stimulant ADHD medication, it is a norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor, not an alpha-2 agonist.
Tizanidine is an alpha-2 agonist, but it is used for muscle spasticity, not ADHD.
Methylphenidate is a stimulant and the first-line treatment for ADHD, but the patient has developed side effects (insomnia and agitation), which necessitate switching to a non-stimulant.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman becomes pregnant while on isotretinoin therapy for severe acne. What is the most likely teratogenic manifestation associated with isotretinoin use during pregnancy?
questions.solution:

Explanation:
•    Isotretinoin, a retinoid, is highly teratogenic and associated with severe craniofacial abnormalities (e.g., cleft palate, ear malformations).
•    It can also cause cardiac defects, but craniofacial anomalies are most characteristic. Neural tube defects and limb malformations are not typically linked to isotretinoin.

mepolizumab and benralizumab target IL-5 or its receptor and are specifically used for eosinophilic asthma by reducing eosinophil counts.
secukinumab target IL-17, primarily used for psoriasis or ankylosing spondylitis, not asthma.
Tezepelumab blocks TSLP, which is upstream of the Th2 pathway. It is effective for both eosinophilic and non-eosinophilic asthma.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman has become aware of increasing right sided hearing deficiency which improves in noisy surrounding. Her eardrums are normal. Her hearing tests show: BC-normal. Weber test lateralizes to the right ear. What is the single most likely dx?

Sol: 

It is conductive deafness which makes otosclerosis as the most likely diagnosis.
Rinne's test 
•    air conduction (AC) is normally better than bone conduction (BC) 

•    if BC > AC then conductive deafness
Weber's test 
•    in unilateral sensorineural deafness, sound is localised to the unaffected side 
•    in unilateral conductive deafness, sound is localised to the affected side

questions.text: A patient with recurrent episodes of facial paralysis has following findings on examination of oral cavity
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Melkersson Rosental syndrome 
Ref:Read the text below
Sol:
•    Melkersson–Rosenthal syndrome (MRS) is a rare, neuro-mucocutaneous disease which presents as orofacial swelling, facial palsy and fissured tongue. 
•    These symptoms may occur simultaneously or, more frequently, with a oligosymptomatic or monosymptomatic pattern. 
•    Swelling, that is the most common initial finding, may mimic hereditary or acquired angioedema, a disorder caused by histamine or bradykinin-mediated plasma-leakage affecting subcutaneous and/or submucosal tissue. 
•    The differential diagnosis of MRS includes also chronic inflammatory and infective diseases characterized by granulomatous infiltration, as well as rosacea, contact dermatitis, allergic reactions and Bell’s palsy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true of primary hyperparathyroidism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

It is usually caused by an adenoma of a single parathyroid gland.

•    "Primary HPT can be divided pathologically into adenoma, hyperplasia, and carcinoma. Adenomas clearly are the most prevalent entity representing 80-85% of cases.
•    Hyperplasia is the second most common diagnosis constituting 15% of cases. Carcinoma represents <1% of total cases.
•    Double adenoma has been found in approximately 5% of the time, and complicates the clinical distinction between adenoma and hyperplasia.
•    Histologically, normal parathyroid tissue shows a cell to fat ratio of 1:1. Hypercellular parathyroid tissue is typified by the loss of the normal amount of fat. 
•    In primary hyperparathryroidism there is usually hypercalciuria. Secondary hyperparathyroidism may progress to tertiary but primary does not.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for curing patients with symptomatic arrhythmias as a result of conduction over an accessory pathway in patients with the Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Radiofrequency catheter ablation of accessory pathway
Reference: Read the text below
Sol: 
•    Sudden death might complicate the follow-up of symptomatic patients with the Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome (WPW) and might be the first event in patients with asymptomatic WPW.
•    The risk of sudden death is increased in some clinical situations. Generally, the noninvasive studies are unable to predict the risk of sudden death correctly . The electrophysiological study is the best means to detect the risk of sudden death and to evaluate the nature of symptoms.
•    Methods used to define the prognosis of WPW are well-defined. At first the maximal rate of conduction through the accessory pathway is evaluated; programmed atrial stimulation using 1 and 2 extrastimuli delivered at different cycle lengths is then used to determine the accessory pathway refractory period and to induce a supraventricular tachycardia.
•    These methods should be performed in the control state and repeated in adrenergic situations either during exercise test or more simply during a perfusion of small doses of isoproterenol. The induction of an atrial fibrillation with rapid conduction through the accessory pathway (> 240/min in control state, > 300/min after isoproterenol) is the sign of a form of WPW at risk of sudden death. 
•    Radiofrequency catheter ablation is a recently introduced non-surgical technique for curing patients with arrhythmias as a result of conduction over an accessory pathway in patients with the Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome

questions.text: A patient presents with atrial fibrillation and later they revert to sinus rhythm. Under which of the following circumstances is the patient more likely to remain in sinus rhythm?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Short history of AF 
Ref– Read the text below
Sol:
•    The patient with very recent onset of atrial fibrillation is more likely to stay in sinus rhythm. 
•    Atrial fibrillation in older patients is more likely to be associated with structural heart disease.
•    Anticoagulation should have no effect on the risk of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. An enlarged left atrium is unlikely to remain in sinus rhythm.
•    Those presenting with a relatively slow ventricular rate and, especially if they are not on betablockers, Calcium antagonists or digoxin, are likely to have chronic atrial fibrillation.

choices.text: Antibiotics should be given if a source of infection can be identified

questions.text: A 26-year-old man is found to have acute leukemia. Three weeks after initiation of chemotherapy he has a body temperature spike to 38.9 C (102 F), with a white blood cell count of 500/mm. Which of the following is true regarding this clinical situation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Bacteremia, if present, would most likely be caused by pseudomonas and other gram-negative bacilli

•    The leading cause of death in cancer patients is infection. Fever developing during the course of treatment for cancer demands careful investigation for infection by all classes of pathogens: bacteria, viruses, yeasts, and protozoans.
•    Pneumonia is common but difficult to diagnose. There is scant sputum production, and often the chest roentgenographic findings are misleadingly normal. Gram-negative bacilli are responsible for most pneumonias and bacteremias.
•    The skin, mucous membranes, and catheter sites are common portals of entry. In the absence of an obvious source of infection, it is essential to begin empirical antibiotic therapy aimed at the most common organisms.
•    An antipseudomonal penicillin plus an aminoglycoside is a commonly used regimen.
•    Both chemotherapy and the tumor lysis syndrome can cause fever, but infection is much more likely to be the cause

questions.text: Tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) is characterized by all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Hypercalcemia

Tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) is an oncologic emergency that is caused by massive tumor cell lysis with the release of large amounts of potassium, phosphate, and nucleic acids into the systemic circulation. The metabolic consequences include hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, secondary hypocalcemia, hyperuricemia, and acute kidney injury. High levels of both uric acid and phosphate increase the severity of acute kidney injury because uric acid precipitates readily in the presence of calcium phosphate crystals, and calcium phosphate precipitates readily in the presence of uric acid crystals.

A BIS value of 75 indicates that the patient may be under light anesthesia, and increasing the dose of the volatile anesthetic is appropriate to deepen the anesthesia level.

questions.text: During a general anesthesia procedure, a 45-year-old male with no significant medical history suddenly develops bronchospasm, hypotension, and generalized urticaria. Which of the following medications is most likely to have caused this reaction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Rocuronium

Rocuronium, a neuromuscular blocking agent, is known to cause allergic reactions, including anaphylaxis, which can present with bronchospasm, hypotension, and urticaria. Although other medications can cause allergic reactions, neuromuscular blocking agents are more commonly implicated in perioperative anaphylaxis.

questions.text: During CPR, a second rescuer arrives and can assist. What is the most appropriate compression-to-ventilation ratio for a two-rescuer adult CPR scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

30:2  
•    For adult CPR with two rescuers, the recommended compression-to-ventilation ratio is 30:2. 
•    This means 30 chest compressions followed by 2 breaths, ensuring that compressions are performed at a rate of 100-120 per minute.

questions.text: Which of the following local anesthetics is associated with a higher risk of cardiotoxicity, including the potential for arrhythmias?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Bupivacaine
 Bupivacaine is most cardiotoxic local anesthetic agent.

questions.text: Which of the following components of the anesthesia machine is responsible for preventing the delivery of a hypoxic gas mixture to the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The hypoxic guard system (proportioning system)  
The hypoxic guard system is designed to prevent the delivery of a hypoxic gas mixture by ensuring that the proportion of oxygen does not fall below a safe level, typically maintaining a minimum oxygen concentration of 25% when nitrous oxide is used.

questions.text: A known alcoholic was prescribed on an anticraving agent after his investigations revealed normal LFT. The patient started complaining of cough after 2 weeks. CBC revealed AEC of 1321 cells/µL and increase in total IgE was seen. The causative agent most probably is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)


Solution: History and investigations are suggestive of drug induced eosinophilic pneumonia
Naltrexone:
●    MOA: blocks µ-opioid receptors
●    Reduces craving and reward in response to opioid and alcohol consumption
●    Naloxone challenge test is advised as naltrexone can precipitate opioid withdrawal (Naloxone is preferred for test as its opioid antagonism lasts less than 1 hour but those of naltrexone and nalmefene may persist more than 24 hours)
●    Hepatic toxicity (dose related) → ⸫ C/I in liver failure
●    Can cause eosinophilic pneumonia.
Reference: Stahl’s Essential Psychopharmacology- Prescriber’s Guide, 5th edition; Page 467-470
    Kaplan & Sadock’s Pocket Handbook of Psychiatric Drug Treatment, 7th edition, Page 176-177

questions.text: A 40-year-old man came with complains of premature ejaculations. The combination of squeeze therapy and sensate focus technique was advised. This method is known as
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


Solution: 
Premature Ejaculation:
●    This is defined as ejaculation before the completion of satisfactory sexual activity for both partners
●    Causes can be psychological (performance anxiety) or biological (uncommon)
●    Treatment includes pharmacotherapy and psychotherapy
●    Masters’ and Johnson’s technique:
›    Includes 
▪    Sensate focus technique
▪    Squeeze therapy (Seman’s technique)
Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry by Niraj Ahuja, 7th edition; Page 130-131

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl was brought to a psychiatrist with delayed language development, stereotyped movements and impairment in social communication. On examination, the child was having microcephaly. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


Solution:
Rett’s syndrome:
●    Described by Andreas Rett
●    It is an unusual syndrome in girls characterized by initial normal development followed by head growth deceleration and development of specific findings
●    X-linked Dominant disorder
●    Due to MeCP2 gene development which is required for normal brain development
●    Clinical features:
›    Regression of milestones after 1-2 years of normal development
›    Hand-wringing movements
›    Microcephaly after birth (not seen at birth)
›    Language skills are lost
›    Low IQ
Reference: New Oxford Textbook of Psychiatry, 2nd edition; Page 1636-1637
    Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition; Page 1165-1166

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient reports that over the last 3 months she has lost her appetite and interest in her usual activities, and often feels that life is not worth living. Compared with typical sleep, in this patient the percentage of REM sleep, percentage of delta sleep, and sleep latency, respectively, are most likely to
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


This woman’s symptoms indicate that she is likely to be experiencing a major depressive episode. Sleep in major depression is associated with increased REM sleep, reduced delta sleep, and increased sleep latency.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department with history of short lasting episodes of behavioural changes and unresponsiveness in which he is agitated, accompanied by smacking of lips, and thrashing movements of his limbs. On recovery, the patient is not able to recall the episode. Further history does not reveal any stressors. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

(Temporal lobe epilepsy)

This is a classic case of temporal lobe epilepsy. Presence of amnesia and short lasting behavioural changes suggest the diagnosis.

questions.text:
Which one of the following is correct about the fetal physiology?
1: Liver is the earliest site of erythropoiesis in embryology
2: The most predominant haemoglobin in intra uterine life is HbF
3: Fetal RBC is acid and alkali resistant RBC
4: Fetal haemoglobin has low O2 affinity
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

2 and 3 are correct

The earliest site of erythropoiesis is yolk sac. HbF is 75% of all Hb in intrauterine life. Due to presence of HbF, the fetal RBC is acid and alkali resistant. Fetal Hb has high O2 affinity since there is low 2,3 DPG.

choices.text: Give Anti-D injection to the patient
Check blood group of her 3 babies delivered in past.

questions.text: A 39 years old G4 P3 L3 has Rh negative pregnancy. Her spouse is Rh positive. She is 28 weeks pregnant. What should be the next step in the management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Check ICT of the patient

We should now know whether the patient is iso-immunised or not. The test called ICT is going to detect Anti-D in the patient’s body. ICT is the next step.

questions.text: A 32 years old G2P1L1 patient has 30 weeks of gestation. There is a twin pregnancy with no intervening septum of membranes in between the two babies. Which of the following is a specific complication in this type of twin pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cord entanglement

No septum would mean that there is MCMA type of twin pregnancy. In this type, the two babies are floating in the same amniotic sac and hence there is a chance of cord entanglement and death. This complication is not seen in any other type of twin.

choices.text: Give her steroids and wait for the course to get over and then do induction of labour
Give her steroids and wait for the course to get over and then do LSCS
Give her steroids but induce the labour immediately
Give her steroids and continue pregnancy till 34 weeks.

questions.text: A 23 years old primigravida with 31 weeks of gestation has come to the emergency department with eclamptic seizures. She is stabilized first and then she is treated by MgSO4 therapy. Her BP is reduced by inj. Labetalol to 146/96mm Hg. Her fetus is in cephalic presentation and her pelvis is adequate. Fetal HR is 150 per minute. What should be the next line of management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Eclampsia requires immediate termination of pregnancy. We must give steroids but we must not wait for 48 hours since eclampsia is a threat to maternal life.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions cannot cause IUGR?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Gestational diabetes

APLA syndrome causes thrombosis and hence the vessels provide less blood flow to placenta. Overt DM can cause vasculopathy which would cause uteroplacental insufficiency. Circumvallate placenta has small chorionic plate and hence there is small functional placenta. All of these conditions can cause IUGR. Gestational diabetes is associated with macrosomia.

questions.text: A 23 years old Primigravida has a full-term pregnancy. On doing pelvic examination, it was found that there was absence of one ala of sacrum. What is this condition called as?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Naegle’s pelvis

Naegle’s pelvis has only one ala of sacrum. Robert’s pelvis has no ala of sacrum. Osteomalacic pelvis has tri-radiate inlet. All the above cases are cases of contracted pelvis.

questions.text: Which of the following cases should not be subjected to vaginal delivery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Breech with preterm labour

Breech presentation with preterm labour should not be delivered vaginally since preterm babies will develop intraventricular hemorrhage due to sudden compression and decompression.

questions.text: There is a patient who is third time pregnant. She had 2 abortions in her past pregnancies. What will be the maximum limit for which we can wait and watch for second stage of labour in this patient if epidural analgesia is given to her?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

4 hours

Nulliparous patient and multiparous patient have maximum limit of 3 hours and 2 hours respectively. If epidural analgesia is given then we can wait for 1 hour more. So, the maximum limit is 4 hours in this case.

choices.text: 2 or more accelerations in 20-40 minutes and the accelerations must last for at least 15 seconds with increase in heart rate by 15 beats from the baseline.
3 or more accelerations in 20-40 minutes and the accelerations must last for at least 15 seconds with increase in heart rate by 15 beats from the baseline.
2 or more accelerations in 20-40 minutes and the accelerations must last for at least 10 seconds with increase in heart rate by 10 beats from the baseline.
3 or more accelerations in 20-40 minutes and the accelerations must last for at least 10 seconds with increase in heart rate by 10 beats from the baseline.

questions.text: A 27 years old primigravida is 30 weeks pregnant. She is subjected to NON-STRESS-TEST for decreased fetal movements. What is the requirement for labelling the NST as REACTIVE NST?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

2 or more accelerations in 20-40 minutes and the accelerations must last for at least 10 seconds with increase in heart rate by 10 beats from the baseline.

Acceleration is defined as an increase in the heart rate by 15 beats for 15 seconds but if the fetus is smaller than 32 weeks then the definition is 10 beats and 10 seconds.

There must be 2 or more accelerations in 20-40 minutes.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not a component of BIOPHYSICAL PROFILE?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Daily fetal movement count

questions.text: As per the latest partogram by WHO (LABOUR CARE GUIDE), active labour is defined as cervical dilation of how many centimetres?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

5cm

questions.text: Which of the following drugs’ usage in pregnancy is responsible for vaginal adenosis and vaginal clear cell cancer in the baby?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
 

Diethylstilbesterol

Diethylstilbesterol exposure in utero causes Mullerian anomalies, cervical collar, T shaped uterus, clear cell cancer of vagina, vaginal adenosis, cervical cancer and dysplasia. It got banned in 1970s.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an estrogenic change in the endometrium?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Corkscrewing of glands

Corkscrewing of glands is seen in secretory phase of endometrial cycle. This is a progesteronic change. All other changes mentioned are estrogenic changes.

questions.text: When is the maximum level of progesterone seen in the serum?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Day 22 of menstrual cycle

Progesterone is maximum when corpus luteum is maximally active. This happens on DAY 21 or DAY 22 of cycle. If the value is >3ng/ml then this means the cycle is ovulatory cycle.

questions.text: Amenorrhoea due to Sheehan’s syndrome is hormonally termed as?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism

Sheehan syndrome is pituitary stalk necrosis caused by hypoxia due to PPH.  Due to this, there is deficiency of LH and FSH. This leads to reduced levels of E and P. This is qualified as hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

questions.text: If there is a girl who has attained thelarche, she will be considered as a case of primary amenorrhoea if she does not get menarche within _____ years.  (fill in the blank)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

3 years

Primary amenorrhoea means no menses till the age of 15 years or no menses and no secondary sexual characters till the age of 13 years of no menses even after 3 years of thelarche.

questions.text: A 32 years old nulliparous female had hirsutism, breast atrophy and clitoromegaly. On evaluation it was found that she had an ovarian tumour. It was removed and sent for histopathology exam. The following picture was seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Leydig cell tumour

The arrow is pointing towards REINKE’s crystals. These are seen in androblastoma cases e.g. Leydig cell tumour of ovary. This tumour produces testosterone and causes heterosexual precocious puberty.

questions.text:
Which one of the biochemical changes would not be seen due to PCOS?
1: High testosterone
2: High FSH
3: High LH
4: High SHBG
5: High insulin 
6: High progesterone
7: High Prolactin
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

2,4,6,7

questions.text: A 73 years old post-menopausal patient has cancer of cervix with rt sided hydronephrosis due to ureteric obstruction caused by cancer. what is the stage of this disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Stage 3

choices.text: Take one more pill of 1500 mcg after 12 hours
Take one more pill of 750 mcg after 12 hours
No need to take any pill now.
Check UPT now and if it is negative then no need to take any pill now.

questions.text: A 23 years old nulliparous patient has had an unprotected intercourse 24 hours ago. She has taken one pill of LNG 750mcg as an emergency contraceptive now. What should be the next plan of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Take one more pill of 750 mcg after 12 hours

LNG is an emergency contraceptive. It has to be taken as 1500 mcg one tablet or 750 mcg 2 tablets 12 hours apart.

questions.text: A 27 years old P2L2 patient is a lactating mother. Her baby is 18 months old now. She has irregular menses which are in the pattern on oligomenorrhoea. Which one is the most suitable contraceptive in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

COC pills

COC pills are best for regularising the menses. COC pills can be given after 6 months of delivery since the patient is not doing exclusive breast feeding to the baby now.

questions.text: A 28 years old nulliparous patient has history of vaginal discharge which occurs on day 12-13 of her cycle. There is no sign of inflammation and there is no foul smell. Her vaginal pH is 4.2. What must be the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Physiological leucorrhoea

No inflammation, no foul smell and normal pH would mean that this is physiological white discharge caused due to estrogenic activity in the mid-cycle. It is endocervical fluid.

questions.text: When is the ideal time of doing HSG in a patient with regular cycles of 28 days and who is not able to conceive?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

Day 10

It should be done after menses but before midcycle. So, day-10 is apt for the test.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not a risk factor for the development of endometrial cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

Raloxifene

Raloxifene is a SERM. It is anti-estrogenic on endometrium. It does not increase the risk of endometrial cancer.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not seen in a case of MRKH syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

Ovarian dysgenesis

MRKH syndrome is a case of Mullerian agenesis in which uterus, cervix and vagina are absent. There are associated renal, skeletal and CVS anomalies possible. Ovarian development is normal in this case. Hence, hormonal levels are normal in this case. Patient presents with primary amenorrhoea.

questions.text: Which of the following is best indicator of severe HIE?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hypotonia

questions.text: A child has 3 days of watery diarrhea, vomiting and decreased level of consciousness. All of the following are differential diagnosis except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

HUS does not usually cause altered sensorium in children.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for atypical HUS ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Eculizumab (anti-C5) is the drug of choice for aHUS in children and adults

questions.text: Out of the following, which clinical feature is not seen in Down syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Caudal regression syndrome is seen in Infants of Diabetic Mothers

questions.text: An infant has respiratory distress, high respiratory rate and scaphoid abdomen, in the emergency. What should be avoided?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Bag and mask ventilation is absolutely contraindicated in suspected diaphragmatic hernia

choices.text: MR s/c on left arm, and Oral vitamin A at 9 months completed
MR s/c on right arm, and Oral vitamin A at 9 months completed
MR s/c on left arm, and Oral vitamin A at 8 months completed
MR s/c on right arm, and Oral vitamin A at 8 months completed

questions.text: A baby received BCG vaccine at birth and has been vaccinated at 14 weeks. Which of the following should be given at the next visit, and site?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: In sickle cell anemia, which drug is used to reduce the vaso-occlusive crisis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Hydroxyurea

questions.text: A 10 weeks baby got DPT vaccine at 6 weeks. The baby got fever>40.5 C and severe inconsolable cry. What should be done at 10 weeks?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

choices.text: Before delivery of shoulder, suction mouth then nose
PPV in non vigorous child after initial steps
Tracheal suctioning in non vigorous baby

questions.text: Meconium stained liquor. What should be done?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: All of these are a criteria for severe acute malnutrition in a 6 month- old child except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Mid arm circumference is used only after 6 months of age for defining SAM

questions.text: A child presents with absent femoral pulses with increased blood pressure in the upper limbs and dilated intercostal arteries. Shown radiological findings were noted. What would be most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Coarctation of aorta
Classic narrowing of aorta just distal to left subclavian origin. Remember CXR will show, fig3 appearance and inferior rib notching involving 3-8th ribs

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with progressive difficulty in swallowing more for liquids than solids for 8 months. A barium swallow was done and is shown in the image. What other investigations should be done to confirm the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

UGIE + manometry
Image is classic bird beak appearance of achalasia cardia and confirmation is on  manometry

questions.text: 52-y/o F presents with dysphagia for both solids & liquids, regurgitation of food with vomiting. In addition, she also complained of severe crushing chest pain. Her cardiac evaluation was normal. Based on barium swallow done make the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Diffuse esophageal spasm
Image shows cork screw appearance due to tertiary non propulsive contractions indicating DES

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presented with tingling and numbness of upper and lower limb extremities. The MRI image is shown. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Multiple sclerosis
MRI image shows characteristic dawson fingers appearance seen in MS, also remember MS shows dissemination in space and time which is another possible question.

questions.text: What is the sign seen in the given Image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Lyre sign
CTA shows characteristic Lyre sign due splaying at carotid bifurcation likely due to chemodectoma/ carotid body tumour.
